citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility is not removing excreta daily from primary enclosures. The outdoor portion of a primary enclosure housing 1
adult French bulldog and 4 juvenile French bulldogs has a large pile of excreta that is approximately 4 inches in height
and 8 inches long. The feces varies from very dry on the edges of the pile to moist where the buildup is the thickest. The
amount of feces present in the enclosure and the various levels of dryness indicate excreta has not been removed on a
daily basis.
Excessive accumulation of excreta inside and under primary enclosures can lead to increased disease hazards or
discomfort for the animals, odors, and/or attract unwanted pests.
The facility must ensure that excreta is removed daily from primary enclosures and from under primary enclosures as
often as necessary to prevent the excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs in the
primary enclosure, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correct by 13 September 2025

The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP and Leptospirosis annually.
2 adult dogs are not up to date on their Distemper, Parvo, or Leptospirosis vaccines:
- #5235 last administered on 3-10-2024
- #5233 last administered on 3-10-2024
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo,
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or
contagious diseases.
Correct by 22 September 2025

The facility was unable to provide the medical record for the annual fecal exam performed by the Attending Veterinarian
on 7 July 2025. Failure to document the results of all screening and routine tests may interfere with the ability of APHIS
officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Medical records must be maintained and include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required
or recommended test or examination.
The facility is not properly documenting the dates of administration for all vaccines and treatments being administered to
the dogs. The individual medical records for the adult dogs has the name of the various treatments (ivermectin, pyrantel,
safeguard, 7-way vaccine, etc) and the month they were administered but does not document the actual date they were
given to the dogs. Failure to record the dates for all treatments administered does not allow for APHIS officials to
determine if adequate veterinary care has been provided for the animals
The facility must ensure that the names of all vaccines and treatments administered, and the dates of administration are
recorded and maintained.
Correct by 22 September 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility is not removing excreta daily from primary enclosures. The outdoor portion of a primary enclosure housing 1 
adult French bulldog and 4 juvenile French bulldogs has a large pile of excreta that is approximately 4 inches in height 
and 8 inches long. The feces varies from very dry on the edges of the pile to moist where the buildup is the thickest. The 
amount of feces present in the enclosure and the various levels of dryness indicate excreta has not been removed on a 
daily basis.  
Excessive accumulation of excreta inside and under primary enclosures can lead to increased disease hazards or 
discomfort for the animals, odors, and/or attract unwanted pests. 
The facility must ensure that excreta is removed daily from primary enclosures and from under primary enclosures as 
often as necessary to prevent the excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs in the 
primary enclosure, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors. 
Correct by 13 September 2025 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently 
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP and Leptospirosis annually.  
 2 adult dogs are not up to date on their Distemper, Parvo, or Leptospirosis vaccines: 
- #5235 last administered on 3-10-2024 
- #5233 last administered on 3-10-2024 
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the 
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo, 
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination 
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or 
contagious diseases.  
Correct by 22 September 2025 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The facility was unable to provide the medical record for the annual fecal exam performed by the Attending Veterinarian 
on 7 July 2025. Failure to document the results of all screening and routine tests may interfere with the ability of APHIS 
officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.  
Medical records must be maintained and include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required 
or recommended test or examination.  
 
The facility is not properly documenting the dates of administration for all vaccines and treatments being administered to 
the dogs. The individual medical records for the adult dogs has the name of the various treatments (ivermectin, pyrantel, 
safeguard, 7-way vaccine, etc) and the month they were administered but does not document the actual date they were 
given to the dogs. Failure to record the dates for all treatments administered does not allow for APHIS officials to 
determine if adequate veterinary care has been provided for the animals 
The facility must ensure that the names of all vaccines and treatments administered, and the dates of administration are 
recorded and maintained. 
Correct by 22 September 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
